title: Should you inform a debt collector you're are judgment proof? If they do decide to get a judgment, should you show up for court
question: I am 60, long term unemployed, living off my IRA...just waiting to start collecting Social Security. My only major asset is my mobile home, which as a Homestead Declaration on it. Should I tell the debt collector that I have no assets they can take, and even if they get the judgment, it won't do them any good, but I will show up for any court date. Should I still appear in court, even if I don't have a real defense?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Social security,Lawsuits and disputes,Summons and complaint,Default judgment
answers: Also, you should be aware of your rights under the Fair Debt Collections Act. If the debt collectors are repeatedly threatening to file suit, but never actually do it, this may violate the FDCA. They can tell you of their intent to sue, if they actually plan on doing it. However, they are not supposed to make idle threats to try and scare you into paying.

If you are served with a summons and complaint, do NOT ignore it. You need to file a response within the time stated on the summons. If you don't respond to the complaint, the collector can (and will) get a default judgment against you. Inability to pay a judgment is not a defense, and it will not prevent them from obtaining a judgment.

You should contact an attorney who knows the FDCPA and Rosenthal Act. These statutes provide protection from debt collector abuse, as well as statutory damages payable by the debt collector. Depending on what was said or done by the debt collector, you might be able to recover damages from them, or you could use the potential violations as leverage to resolve the debt.

I do not think that communicating your financial circumstances to the debt collector will be of any benefit. They do not believe debts. They run their own asset searches. As far as going to court, if the collector decides to sue you, it will pay the court filing fee and other expenses. You will be served with Summons and Complaint. Before you can go to court, you will need to file an Answer (or other pleading) with the court and either pay the court filing fee or as for a fee waiver. I would advise filing an Answer and waiting for the court date. I have seen quite a few instances in which the collector decides to dismiss the case ("without prejudice") instead of sending an attorney and witnesses to court to spend a day. Trials in collection cases in Los Angeles are set about a year after the Answer is filed, or longer. I suggest that you not waste your time talking to the collector on the phone. The collector is more likely to go away if he/she cannot reach you.
Being judgment proof is a circumstance, not a legal defense. You can tell them all you want, just like people tell debt collectors they will file bankruptcy, it means nothing.

I doubt telling a debt collector that you are judgment proof will stop him from filing a lawsuit. Many collection agencies threaten to file a lawsuit but never get around to actually doing it. If the case goes to court you should defend it but not be saying you are judgment proof. You might have a defense of statute of limitations if the debt is very old. Maybe the amount the debt collector is seeking to obtain is wrong.

Having no "real defense" or believing yourself to be judgment proof should not prevent you from fighting the lawsuit. Debt collectors often file lawsuits without having the necessary documents to prove their case. Informing them that you are judgment proof is not going to stop them from obtaining a judgment and attempting to collect anyway. If you do nothing, they will eventually try to levy your bank account and you will have to file exemptions and go through a small hassle of your own.
